A battle of jazz between Bubby
Johnson and The Bachelors, two of
BaltimOre's most prominent dance
orchestras, will be featured at the
Freshman-Sophomore Dance on Saturday, April 18, in the Johns Hopkins Gymnasium.
According to John Ghingher, chairman of the joint dance committee,
this is the first time in the history
of the University that the two classes have joined together to present
such an affair. It should prove to be
one of the outstanding events in the
undergraduate social season, he said.
"The gymnasium," stated Bob
Ward, president of the Freshman
class, "because of its spacious floor,
will afford an excellent place for the
dance. Plans are being made to decorate the gymnasium to provide a
more presentable scene for the affair."
Publicity Committee At Work
A publicity committee headed by
Stanley M. Finkel is busy at work
planning posters, announcements, and
newspaper priblicity. Finkel said: "We
will need the support of every student in the school and as many more
outsiders to make the dance a success. We have secured two orchestras that we believe to be outstandcircles

because of their excellent arrangements and presentations of popular
music."
The price of admission will be
$1.25 stag or drag, and dancing will
be from 9 until 1. Arrangements are
being made to provide seating and
check room facilities at the gym.
First Dance In Gym
Ghingher said: "This is the first
time that the gymnasium at the
Hopkins has ever been used for a
dance. Other universities all over the
country, however, make use of their
gyms in such a way, and it is high
time that the organizations at the
Hopkins had a place large enough
and with suitable acoustics to hold
their social affairs without having to
go off the campus."

Election of the president of the
Student Council will begin on Thursday, April 2, and class representatives to the Council will be chosen on
closely following dates.
Mead Johnson, president of the
Council, explained that the election
dates have been made earlier mainly so that the newly elected members will have a chance to serve under the guidance of the old representatives before full responsibility is
placed on their shoulders. He said:
"The Student Council is thus at a
distinct advantage because the requirements of both the position of
president and member, are such that
experience is indispensable."
All To Vote
So that the election will be a representative one, the Council has decided that members of all classes will
be permitted to vote for the president and for individual class representatives whether they have or have
not paid class dues.
"An invitation is extended to every student in the University to take
part in these elections in order to
choose an efficient, experienced, mature, and well represented group to
the Council," Johnson added.
The dates for the election of the
president and members of the Student Council are as follows:
For President—
Nominations, Thursday, April 2
Primaries, Monday, April 6
Final Election, Thursday, April 9
For Senior Representatives—
Nominations, Monday, April 13
Primaries, Wednesday, April 15
Final Election, Thursday, April 16
For Junior Representatives—
Nominations, Monday, April 20
Primaries, Wednesday, April 22
Final Election, Thursday, April 23
For Sophomore Representatives—
Nominations, Monday, April 27
Primaries, Wednesday, April 29
Final Election, Thursday, April 30
Election rules:
1. All ballots must be signed.
2. All students in the University
have the privilege of voting for the
president of the Student Council.
3. No student may vote by proxy.
4. Stuffing of ballot box is a punishable offense.

manager.

next month. At present, Jesse Borden and Kenneth Zierler are conducting classes to groom prospective
candidates for these positions.
On the business staff, elections for
the board of control positions will
be held at a separate meeting of this
staff after the general elections.
Selection of advertising manager, circulation manager, office manager,
and copy and filing manager will be
made.
